column4: how can i find out what my windows HDD address is? i.e. (hd0,0) i am running a dual boot system and need it for the grub boot loader, dont know how to extract that info with ubuntu tried fdisk -l in a terminal but it just spit me back out to user@computer prompt
Did you use wubi?

still no luck with the bootloader still hanging when i select windows, it goes to black screen with "Starting up ... " in white letters and just sits there i have to ctrl+alt+del to restart my computer.... and i have to change the boot sequence in my bios to boot into windows
You could just keep guessing at it, just push 'e' at the boot menu and keep trying (hdX,0)

i tried hd0,0 hd 1,0 hd0,1 hd 1,1 all to no avail, i don't think it would be anything else, i changed the boot order to install windows to my slave drive because i installed windows after ubuntu, could that be a possible problem?
Installing Windows after Ubuntu is always tricky. I don't have that much experience with it, but the grub factoid supposedly has a great howto, don't know if that's what you were following or not
i even saved that webpage so i could copy and paste the lines to make sure i didnt typo, just changed the hd location accordingly
Hmmm, but you can still boot from Windows? what does your sudo fdisk -l say again?
yeah i can still boot into windows but i have to change my boot sequence, how do i pastebin? i will pastebin the result of fdisk -l
i guess this is the URL? http://paste.ubuntu.com/23358/
So sdb1 is definitely your Windows install? Not hde1?
Ok, I guess the next thing to do would be to pastebin the contents of /boot/grub/menu.lst
http://paste.ubuntu.com/23360/ contents of /boot/grub/menu.lst
I dunno... start spamming grub-install :P or ask advice from someone smarter than me :-/
lol thanx anyways
nah you got me a little better of an understanding as to why i should have left it the hell alone lol

That idea made sense in my head. setup BIOS such that it avoids grub and automatically boots into windows. Once that is going use a live-cd to boot into Ubuntu and then do a grub-install on the primary drive
But I fail a lot, so take it for what it's worth
I think you need to set your BIOS up so that it automatically boots into Windows, and then once you've done that, boot to a live-cd and do a grub-install on the windows drive
that may work i think i changed the boot sequence before i reinstalled grub
Right, and that's what's ticking windows off
So get it setup such that you can boot into Windows and Windows only, then live-cd it, then grub-install it, best thing I can think of
ah well time to reboot, reinstall grub hopefully i get it right this time, will return with the results lol
